title: Genesis Chapter 14 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Genesis chapter 14 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Genesis Chapter 14 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Genesis Chapter 14.

questions.question: Who were the four kings mentioned at the beginning of Genesis 14?
options: Amraphel, Arioch, Chedorlaomer, Tidal
Bera, Birsha, Shinab, Shemeber
Abram, Lot, Melchizedek, Aner
Amalekites, Amorites, Rephaims, Emims
questions.correctAnswer: Amraphel, Arioch, Chedorlaomer, Tidal
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:1 lists these four kings explicitly as Amraphel king of Shinar, Arioch king of Ellasar, Chedorlaomer king of Elam, and Tidal king of nations.

questions.question: Which kings did the four kings make war with according to Genesis 14?
options: Bera, Birsha, Shinab, Shemeber, and the king of Bela
Abram, Melchizedek, Lot, and Aner
The Amalekites, Amorites, Rephaims, and Emims
The Egyptians, Canaanites, Hittites, and Jebusites
questions.correctAnswer: Bera, Birsha, Shinab, Shemeber, and the king of Bela
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:2 states these kings were at war with Bera king of Sodom, Birsha king of Gomorrah, Shinab king of Admah, Shemeber king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela (Zoar).

questions.question: Where did the battle take place as mentioned in Genesis 14?
options: Vale of Siddim
Mount Seir
Enmishpat
Valley of Shaveh
questions.correctAnswer: Vale of Siddim
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:3 and 14:8 mention that the battle occurred in the vale of Siddim, which is the salt sea area.

questions.question: For how many years did the kings serve Chedorlaomer before rebelling?
options: Twelve years
Ten years
Thirteen years
Fourteen years
questions.correctAnswer: Twelve years
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:4 states that they served Chedorlaomer for twelve years and rebelled in the thirteenth year.

questions.question: True or False: Abram armed 318 trained servants to rescue his brother Lot.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:14 mentions Abram armed his trained servants, born in his house, numbering 318 to pursue and rescue Lot.

questions.question: Who brought bread and wine to Abram after his victory?
options: Melchizedek, king of Salem
The king of Sodom
Chedorlaomer
Lot
questions.correctAnswer: Melchizedek, king of Salem
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:18 states Melchizedek king of Salem brought forth bread and wine and was priest of the most high God.

questions.question: What did Melchizedek bless Abram with?
options: Blessed be Abram of the most high God, possessor of heaven and earth
Blessed be Abram king of Sodom
Blessed be Abram the warrior
Blessed be Abram, the servant of Chedorlaomer
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed be Abram of the most high God, possessor of heaven and earth
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:19 records Melchizedek’s blessing to Abram as being blessed by the most high God, possessor of heaven and earth.

questions.question: True or False: Abram accepted the goods offered by the king of Sodom after the battle.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:23 shows Abram refused to take anything from the king of Sodom to avoid the appearance of being enriched by him.

questions.question: What was the name of the place also called Kadesh where Chedorlaomer returned after battle?
options: Enmishpat
Hobah
Dan
Shaveh
questions.correctAnswer: Enmishpat
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:7 mentions Enmishpat, which is Kadesh, where Chedorlaomer came and smote the Amalekites and Amorites.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Abram did not take from the king of Sodom "from a thread even to a _______."
options: shoelatchet
bag
ring
crown
questions.correctAnswer: shoelatchet
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:23 explicitly states Abram would not take even a thread to a shoelatchet from the king of Sodom.

questions.question: Who escaped and told Abram about Lot's capture?
options: One that had escaped
Melchizedek
The king of Sodom
Chedorlaomer
questions.correctAnswer: One that had escaped
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:13 mentions an escaped man who came and told Abram the Hebrew about Lot’s capture.

questions.question: True or False: The kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled into the slimepits of the vale of Siddim and many fell there.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:10 describes the vale of Siddim being full of slimepits where the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled and many fell.

questions.question: What did Abram do at night against the kings who took Lot captive?
options: Divided himself and his servants and struck them
Made peace with them
Fled from them
Sent a messenger to negotiate
questions.correctAnswer: Divided himself and his servants and struck them
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:15 states Abram divided himself and his servants by night, smote them, and pursued them.

questions.question: Where did Abram pursue the captors of Lot to?
options: Dan and Hobah
Jerusalem and Salem
Zoar and Admah
Shinar and Ellasar
questions.correctAnswer: Dan and Hobah
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:14-15 say Abram pursued them unto Dan and then Hobah, which is on the left hand of Damascus.

questions.question: Who were the three confederates with Abram mentioned in Genesis 14?
options: Mamre, Eshcol, Aner
Bera, Birsha, Shinab
Amraphel, Arioch, Tidal
Lot, Melchizedek, Chedorlaomer
questions.correctAnswer: Mamre, Eshcol, Aner
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:13 identifies Mamre, brother of Eshcol and Aner, as confederates with Abram.

medium.title: Genesis Chapter 14 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Genesis Chapter 14 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is facing overwhelming opposition. Based on Genesis 14, what biblical truth about faith and perseverance can you share?
options: Trust in God and take courageous action to rescue those in need
Avoid confrontation and wait for problems to resolve themselves
Seek help only from human allies and avoid risks
Ignore the situation and focus purely on prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God and take courageous action to rescue those in need
questions.explanation: Abram armed his servants and pursued the captors of Lot, demonstrating faith in God’s protection and courage (Genesis 14:14-16). This teaches us to trust God and act boldly when facing trials.

questions.question: How does Abram’s refusal to accept goods from the king of Sodom teach us about integrity and contentment?
options: He refused riches to avoid the appearance of dishonesty
He wanted to accumulate more wealth secretly
He accepted all goods to reward his servants
He demanded payment for his services
questions.correctAnswer: He refused riches to avoid the appearance of dishonesty
questions.explanation: Abram said he would not take anything from the king of Sodom so that no one could say he made Abram rich, showing integrity and contentment with God’s provision (Genesis 14:22-23).

questions.question: What does Melchizedek’s blessing of Abram teach about recognizing God’s sovereignty in our victories?
options: Victory comes from the Most High God, and we should give Him glory
Victory is solely due to our own strength and wisdom
Blessings are unrelated to spiritual faith
One should seek blessings only for material gain
questions.correctAnswer: Victory comes from the Most High God, and we should give Him glory
questions.explanation: Melchizedek blessed Abram as the possessor of heaven and earth and acknowledged God’s deliverance of enemies, teaching us to glorify God in our successes (Genesis 14:18-20).

questions.question: A believer struggles with generosity. Based on Genesis 14, what biblical principle about stewardship and giving can you share?
options: Giving tithes honors God and acknowledges His provision
Keeping all possessions is the best way to succeed
Generosity is optional and not important
Only give when forced by others
questions.correctAnswer: Giving tithes honors God and acknowledges His provision
questions.explanation: Abram gave Melchizedek tithes of all, demonstrating faithful stewardship and gratitude to God for His blessings (Genesis 14:20).

questions.question: How does Abram’s alliance with Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre demonstrate the importance of fellowship and support in spiritual battles?
options: God uses faithful friends to strengthen us in difficult times
We should rely only on ourselves without support
Alliances are unimportant in spiritual matters
Friends should be avoided during trials
questions.correctAnswer: God uses faithful friends to strengthen us in difficult times
questions.explanation: Abram was confederate with Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre, showing how God provides allies in times of challenge (Genesis 14:13, 14:24).

questions.question: True or False: Abram’s pursuit of Lot’s captors was motivated by personal gain rather than faith and obedience.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Abram acted out of faith and obedience to rescue his brother, not for personal gain, as shown by his refusal to accept riches afterwards (Genesis 14:14-16; 14:22-24).

questions.question: What does the capture of Lot teach about the importance of family responsibility and intercession?
options: Faithful believers should stand up for and rescue their family members in distress
Family struggles should be ignored to avoid conflict
Each person is responsible only for themselves
Intercession is unnecessary when family members suffer
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful believers should stand up for and rescue their family members in distress
questions.explanation: Abram immediately armed his servants to rescue Lot, demonstrating active family responsibility and intercession (Genesis 14:12-14).

questions.question: How does the king of Sodom’s request after Abram’s victory illustrate a biblical principle about humility and generosity?
options: Abram humbly refused to take spoils to avoid boasting
Abram demanded all the spoils for himself
The king of Sodom refused to give anything to Abram
Abram took spoils to prove his power
questions.correctAnswer: Abram humbly refused to take spoils to avoid boasting
questions.explanation: The king of Sodom asked Abram to keep the goods, but Abram refused to take anything, showing humility and avoiding pride (Genesis 14:21-23).

questions.question: True or False: The battle described in Genesis 14 shows that believers should rely on worldly alliances rather than God’s power.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Though alliances are shown, Abram’s faith and God’s deliverance are emphasized, teaching reliance on God’s power (Genesis 14:14-16, 14:18-20).

questions.question: Based on Genesis 14, what can we learn about humility in receiving blessings and rewards?
options: Accept only what is necessary and avoid taking more than needed
Demand all rewards to prove your worth
Refuse to accept any blessings at all
Take riches as a sign of personal success
questions.correctAnswer: Accept only what is necessary and avoid taking more than needed
questions.explanation: Abram allowed only what the young men had eaten and portions for his allies, refusing excess to maintain humility (Genesis 14:23-24).

questions.question: How does Abram’s action of dividing his forces and attacking by night teach us about strategic planning and spiritual discipline?
options: Faith includes wise planning and action alongside prayer
Faith means acting impulsively without preparation
Spiritual discipline excludes practical strategy
Planning shows lack of trust in God
questions.correctAnswer: Faith includes wise planning and action alongside prayer
questions.explanation: Abram divided himself and his servants to attack by night, showing that faith involves wise strategy (Genesis 14:15).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with gratitude. Based on Melchizedek’s blessing in Genesis 14, what truth can encourage them?
options: Recognize God as the possessor of heaven and earth and give Him thanks for deliverance
Ignore God’s role in blessings and focus on self
Gratitude is unnecessary in times of success
Only thank God when things go wrong
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize God as the possessor of heaven and earth and give Him thanks for deliverance
questions.explanation: Melchizedek blessed Abram by acknowledging God’s sovereignty and deliverance, encouraging gratitude to God (Genesis 14:19-20).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Abram armed his trained servants, born in his own house, numbering _____, to pursue the captors of Lot.
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:14 specifies Abram had 318 trained servants born in his house who pursued Lot’s captors.

questions.question: How does the cooperation of the four kings with five in battle teach us about unity and strength in the body of Christ?
options: Unity among believers strengthens their witness and effectiveness
Isolation is better than cooperation
Strength comes only from individual effort
Conflict among leaders is necessary for growth
questions.correctAnswer: Unity among believers strengthens their witness and effectiveness
questions.explanation: The alliance of four kings with five shows strength in unity, a principle for believers to support one another (Genesis 14:8-9).

questions.question: What lesson about forgiveness and reconciliation can we infer from Abram’s treatment of the king of Sodom after the battle?
options: Abram did not seek revenge but acted with integrity, leaving room for reconciliation
Abram punished the king harshly
Abram ignored the king entirely
Abram demanded payment for his help
questions.correctAnswer: Abram did not seek revenge but acted with integrity, leaving room for reconciliation
questions.explanation: Abram’s refusal to take spoils and his respectful interaction with the king of Sodom suggest humility and openness to reconciliation (Genesis 14:21-24).

hard.title: Genesis Chapter 14 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Genesis Chapter 14.

questions.question: Which four kings are mentioned as making war in the opening verse of Genesis 14?
options: Amraphel king of Shinar, Arioch king of Ellasar, Chedorlaomer king of Elam, and Tidal king of nations
Bera king of Sodom, Birsha king of Gomorrah, Shinab king of Admah, and Shemeber king of Zeboiim
Melchizedek king of Salem, Abram the Hebrew, Aner, Eshcol
The king of Bela, the king of Gomorrah, the king of Sodom, and the king of Admah
questions.correctAnswer: Amraphel king of Shinar, Arioch king of Ellasar, Chedorlaomer king of Elam, and Tidal king of nations
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:1 lists these four kings as the ones who made war.

questions.question: What is the significance of the vale of Siddim in the battle described in Genesis 14?
options: It was full of slimepits where some kings fell
It was the place where Abram built an altar
It was the city where Melchizedek ruled
It was a mountain where the kings fled
questions.correctAnswer: It was full of slimepits where some kings fell
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:10 explains that the vale of Siddim was full of slimepits, causing the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah to fall there during the battle.

questions.question: Who is Melchizedek, and what roles does he fulfill in Genesis 14?
options: King of Salem and priest of the most high God
King of Sodom and a military commander
A servant of Abram who fought in the battle
A prophet who warned Abram
questions.correctAnswer: King of Salem and priest of the most high God
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:18 describes Melchizedek as king of Salem and priest of the most high God, establishing his dual role.

questions.question: What was Abram’s response when the king of Sodom offered him the goods after the battle?
options: He refused to take anything to avoid the appearance of being enriched by the king
He accepted all the goods to reward his servants
He demanded half of the goods as a sign of victory
He requested only the prisoners from the battle
questions.correctAnswer: He refused to take anything to avoid the appearance of being enriched by the king
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:23 shows Abram's refusal to take anything from the king of Sodom, even a thread or shoelace, to avoid the claim that the king made him rich.

questions.question: How many trained servants did Abram take to pursue the captors of Lot?
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:14 specifies that Abram armed 318 trained servants born in his house to pursue the captors.

questions.question: Which ancient peoples were defeated by Chedorlaomer and his allies as part of their campaign before the battle with the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah?
options: Rephaims, Zuzims, Emims, Horites, Amalekites, and Amorites
Canaanites, Hittites, Jebusites, and Perizzites
Philistines, Moabites, Edomites, and Ammonites
Babylonians, Assyrians, Medes, and Persians
questions.correctAnswer: Rephaims, Zuzims, Emims, Horites, Amalekites, and Amorites
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:5-7 lists these groups as being defeated by Chedorlaomer and his allies during their military campaign.

questions.question: True or False: The alliance of kings who fought against the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah consisted of four kings fighting against five kings.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:9 explicitly states 'four kings with five,' indicating four kings against five kings.

questions.question: What literary function does Melchizedek’s blessing of Abram serve in the narrative of Genesis 14?
options: It foreshadows the priestly role and divine approval of Abram’s mission
It recounts the genealogy of Abram
It introduces a new covenant with Israel
It marks the end of the battle narrative
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the priestly role and divine approval of Abram’s mission
questions.explanation: Melchizedek’s blessing in Genesis 14:19-20 functions as a typological foreshadowing of divine approval and the priestly role that Abram and his descendants will embody.

questions.question: What does Abram’s refusal to accept the goods from the king of Sodom reveal about his character and faith?
options: His reliance on God alone for provision and refusal to be indebted to earthly powers
His distrust of the king of Sodom’s intentions
His desire to keep all the spoils for his family only
His plan to negotiate better terms later
questions.correctAnswer: His reliance on God alone for provision and refusal to be indebted to earthly powers
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:22-24 shows Abram making a solemn vow not to take anything from the king of Sodom to avoid any claim that he was made rich by men rather than God.

questions.question: The name 'Melchizedek' can be translated as 'king of righteousness.' How does this name relate to his role in Genesis 14?
options: He is both king and priest, embodying righteousness and divine authority
He is the military leader who defeated the kings
He is the king who captured Lot
He is a prophet predicting future events
questions.correctAnswer: He is both king and priest, embodying righteousness and divine authority
questions.explanation: Melchizedek’s dual role as king of Salem and priest of the most high God (Genesis 14:18) aligns with his name's meaning, symbolizing a righteous divine authority.

questions.question: In the historical and cultural context of Genesis 14, what does the taking of Lot and his goods signify?
options: The practice of capturing enemy captives and looting their possessions during warfare
A peaceful exchange between allied kings
A ritual offering to the gods
A symbolic act of covenant renewal
questions.correctAnswer: The practice of capturing enemy captives and looting their possessions during warfare
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:12 describes Lot’s capture along with his goods, reflecting the common ancient Near Eastern practice of seizing captives and spoils in war.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'tithes' Abram gives to Melchizedek in Genesis 14?
options: It shows Abram’s recognition of Melchizedek’s priestly authority and God’s supremacy
It is a payment to secure military alliance
It is a tax demanded by the king of Sodom
It symbolizes Abram’s surrender to Melchizedek
questions.correctAnswer: It shows Abram’s recognition of Melchizedek’s priestly authority and God’s supremacy
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:20 says Abram gave Melchizedek tithes of all, indicating Abram’s acknowledgment of Melchizedek’s priesthood and God's sovereignty.

questions.question: Which geographical locations mentioned in Genesis 14 mark the extent of Chedorlaomer’s military campaign?
options: Ashteroth Karnaim, Mount Seir, Enmishpat (Kadesh), Hazezontamar
Jerusalem, Hebron, Bethel, and Shechem
Damascus, Babylon, Nineveh, and Ur
Zoar, Admah, Zeboiim, and Gomorrah
questions.correctAnswer: Ashteroth Karnaim, Mount Seir, Enmishpat (Kadesh), Hazezontamar
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:5-7 lists these locations where Chedorlaomer and allies struck during their campaign.

questions.question: How does the narrative of Genesis 14 emphasize the theme of divine providence and protection?
options: Abram’s victory and recovery of Lot demonstrate God’s intervention on behalf of the faithful
The kings of Sodom defeat Abram’s forces
Lot is permanently lost, showing human failure
Abram negotiates with the gods for success
questions.correctAnswer: Abram’s victory and recovery of Lot demonstrate God’s intervention on behalf of the faithful
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:14-16 shows Abram’s decisive victory and rescue of Lot, highlighting divine favor and protection over Abram and his allies.

questions.question: What is the significance of the identification of Enmishpat as Kadesh in Genesis 14:7 in terms of biblical geography?
options: It links the battle narrative to a historically recognized city in the wilderness, anchoring the story in real geography
It introduces a fictional location for narrative purposes
It shows the transition from Egypt to Canaan
It marks the birthplace of Abram
questions.correctAnswer: It links the battle narrative to a historically recognized city in the wilderness, anchoring the story in real geography
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:7 clarifies Enmishpat as Kadesh, a known city in the wilderness, grounding the story in the ancient Near East context.

theological.title: Genesis Chapter 14 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Genesis Chapter 14 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Which four kings led the coalition that waged war in the days of Abram, as described in Genesis 14?
options: Amraphel king of Shinar, Arioch king of Ellasar, Chedorlaomer king of Elam, Tidal king of nations
Bera king of Sodom, Birsha king of Gomorrah, Shinab king of Admah, Shemeber king of Zeboiim
Melchizedek king of Salem, Abram king of Hebron, Lot king of Sodom, Chedorlaomer king of Elam
Pharaoh king of Egypt, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, Darius king of Persia, Cyrus king of Persia
questions.correctAnswer: Amraphel king of Shinar, Arioch king of Ellasar, Chedorlaomer king of Elam, Tidal king of nations
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:1 identifies these four kings as leading the coalition; this illustrates God's providence over earthly rulers (Daniel 2:21, Romans 13:1, Proverbs 21:1, Isaiah 45:1).

questions.question: What was the reason given in Genesis 14 for the twelve years of subjugation followed by rebellion in the thirteenth year?
options: Twelve years they served Chedorlaomer, and in the thirteenth year they rebelled
They were faithful servants for twelve years and then sought peace
They were at war with other nations for twelve years without rebellion
The kings of Sodom and Gomorrah made a treaty with Chedorlaomer
questions.correctAnswer: Twelve years they served Chedorlaomer, and in the thirteenth year they rebelled
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:4 states this clearly, showing the theme of human rebellion against oppression and God's sovereignty over history (Romans 5:20, Isaiah 1:20, Deuteronomy 8:11-14, Jeremiah 2:19).

questions.question: Which peoples did Chedorlaomer and his allies defeat during their campaign, according to Genesis 14?
options: Rephaims in Ashteroth Karnaim, Zuzims in Ham, Emims in Shaveh Kiriathaim, Horites in mount Seir, Amalekites, and Amorites
Egyptians, Babylonians, Philistines, Moabites, and Edomites
Israelites, Canaanites, Hittites, Jebusites, and Girgashites
Persians, Medes, Greeks, Romans, and Syrians
questions.correctAnswer: Rephaims in Ashteroth Karnaim, Zuzims in Ham, Emims in Shaveh Kiriathaim, Horites in mount Seir, Amalekites, and Amorites
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:5-7 lists these groups defeated by Chedorlaomer, showing God's control over nations and judgment on the wicked (Deuteronomy 2:10-11, Joshua 12:4, Psalm 110:6, Isaiah 10:5).

questions.question: Where did the battle between the coalition of four kings and the five kings of the cities of the plain take place?
options: Vale of Siddim, which is the salt sea
Mount Sinai
Valley of Elah
Plain of Megiddo
questions.correctAnswer: Vale of Siddim, which is the salt sea
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:3 and 14:8 specify this location; the vale full of slimepits symbolizes judgment and destruction (Genesis 19:24-25, Deuteronomy 29:23, Psalm 83:7, Revelation 20:9).

questions.question: According to Genesis 14, who was taken captive during the battle and later rescued by Abram?
options: Lot, Abram's brother's son
Melchizedek, king of Salem
Bera, king of Sodom
Chedorlaomer, king of Elam
questions.correctAnswer: Lot, Abram's brother's son
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:12 and 14:16 describe Lot's capture and Abram's rescue, demonstrating God's providential care and foreshadowing Christ as the Redeemer who rescues captives (Luke 19:10, Isaiah 53:4, Psalm 34:18, John 10:11).

questions.question: How many trained servants did Abram take to rescue Lot, according to Genesis 14?
options: Three hundred and eighteen
Five hundred
One thousand
Two hundred
questions.correctAnswer: Three hundred and eighteen
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:14 states this number; it highlights Abram's faith and readiness, paralleling God’s call for faithful warriors in spiritual battles (Exodus 12:37, Judges 7:2, 1 Timothy 6:12, Ephesians 6:11).

questions.question: What did Melchizedek, king of Salem, bring forth to Abram after his victory, and what was his priestly title?
options: Bread and wine; priest of the most high God
Gold and silver; priest of Baal
Water and oil; priest of the Lord God
Fruit and grain; priest of El Elyon
questions.correctAnswer: Bread and wine; priest of the most high God
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:18 shows Melchizedek offering bread and wine and being priest of the Most High God, prefiguring Christ’s priesthood and the Eucharist (Hebrews 7:1-3, Psalm 110:4, John 6:35, Matthew 26:26-28).

questions.question: What blessing did Melchizedek pronounce upon Abram?
options: Blessed be Abram of the most high God, possessor of heaven and earth
Blessed be Abram, king of the earth and sea
Blessed be Abram, ruler of the nations
Blessed be Abram, conqueror of kings
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed be Abram of the most high God, possessor of heaven and earth
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:19 records this blessing, affirming God's sovereignty and Abram’s special relationship with Him, pointing to the Creator as possessor of all (Psalm 24:1, Colossians 1:16, Revelation 4:11, Isaiah 40:12).

questions.question: What did Abram give to Melchizedek as an acknowledgment of his priesthood and God's blessing?
options: Tithes of all
A portion of spoils
A sacrifice of animals
A gift of silver and gold
questions.correctAnswer: Tithes of all
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:20 says Abram gave tithes to Melchizedek, symbolizing acknowledgement of God's priesthood and foreshadowing New Testament teachings on giving and priesthood (Leviticus 27:30, Hebrews 7:2, Malachi 3:10, 2 Corinthians 9:7).

questions.question: How did Abram respond to the king of Sodom's offer to give him the people but let him keep the goods?
options: Abram refused to take anything to avoid being indebted
Abram accepted all the goods and people
Abram asked for half the goods and half the people
Abram requested only the goods
questions.correctAnswer: Abram refused to take anything to avoid being indebted
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:22-23 shows Abram's refusal to accept anything, emphasizing his dependence on God alone and rejection of worldly riches that could compromise his testimony (1 Timothy 6:10, Proverbs 3:9, Philippians 4:11-13, James 1:27).

questions.question: What reason did Abram give for not taking anything from the king of Sodom?
options: Lest the king should say, I have made Abram rich
He was already wealthy
He wanted to give all to the poor
He was waiting for God's direct provision
questions.correctAnswer: Lest the king should say, I have made Abram rich
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:23 reveals Abram's concern for God's glory and avoiding the appearance of indebtedness, reflecting biblical teaching on integrity and God’s sole provision (Deuteronomy 8:18, Psalm 44:3, 1 Corinthians 4:7, Acts 3:6).

questions.question: Who were Abram's confederates mentioned in Genesis 14 who helped him in his pursuit to rescue Lot?
options: Mamre, Eshcol, and Aner
Melchizedek, Chedorlaomer, and Tidal
Bera, Birsha, and Shinab
Isaac, Ishmael, and Esau
questions.correctAnswer: Mamre, Eshcol, and Aner
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:13 mentions these allies who supported Abram, illustrating the importance of faithful fellowship and covenantal partnership (Ecclesiastes 4:9-10, Proverbs 27:17, 1 Corinthians 12:12-27, Hebrews 10:24-25).

questions.question: To which location did Abram pursue the kings who had taken Lot captive?
options: Dan
Jericho
Hebron
Beersheba
questions.correctAnswer: Dan
questions.explanation: Genesis 14:14 states Abram pursued them to Dan, signifying God's guidance and Abram’s obedience in deliverance, paralleling God's deliverance of Israel (Exodus 14:13-14, Joshua 1:9, Psalm 18:17, Isaiah 41:10).

questions.question: What was the condition of the vale of Siddim during the battle, and what happened to the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah there?
options: The vale was full of slimepits; the kings fled and fell in them
The vale was dry and easy to traverse; the kings defeated their enemies
The vale was mountainous; the kings set an ambush
The vale was flooded; the kings escaped by boat
questions.correctAnswer: The vale was full of slimepits; the kings fled and fell in them

questions.question: What did Abram recover after defeating the kings who captured Lot?
